feedback_analysis.feedback: Excellent start. The arpeggiated picking pattern is clean, well-paced, and sets the mood of the song perfectly. All notes are clear.
Good transition, but the G# note on the G-string is slightly muted. Double-check that your fretting finger is properly arched to avoid contact with the adjacent string.
This is a very clean and confident chord change. Your rhythm remains perfectly steady, which is crucial for the song's drive.
There's a noticeable buzz on the high E string. Make sure your ring finger is pressing down firmly and positioned right behind the fret.
The most challenging chord of the verse. The B string is not ringing out. Focus on rolling your index finger slightly to apply even pressure across all strings for this barre.
You recovered well from the F chord. The transition to C is smooth and gets the progression back on solid ground.
A slight pause is audible before this change. Practice the C to Dm transition repeatedly to build muscle memory and eliminate the delay.
A solid E7 to end the verse progression. The timing here is good, leading well into the next section.
Your barre chord is stronger here in the chorus. Still a slight mute on the B string, but much improved. Keep building that index finger strength.
The chord is clean, but the first strum was slightly ahead of the beat. Be mindful to stay locked into the tempo, especially during the chorus.
Great timing and execution on this chord. It has the right amount of tension and release needed for the chorus.
Very smooth transition into the Am. The walk-up you mentioned would typically start from here, adding a nice melodic touch.
Again, the F barre chord proves to be the main hurdle. The B and high E strings are slightly muffled. Targeted practice on just this chord will pay off immensely.
Clean chord, but the transition could be faster. Try anticipating the change and moving your fingers as a single unit.
You end the section with a well-played E7, resolving the musical phrase nicely. Good focus all the way to the end.
